title: Teaching
text:
Teaching is one of the most rewarding parts of my job. There’s something deeply satisfying about watching a student go from “I don’t understand R” to confidently analysing their own data, or seeing a field course spark someone’s passion for ecology.
I believe in learning by doing, whether that means getting your hands dirty in the field or wrestling with real datasets in R. Theory matters, but it sticks better when you’ve experienced the messiness of actual ecological data.

title: Biodiversity Forecasting
text: Climate change is reshuffling species distributions worldwide. To respond effectively, we need to anticipate these changes, but our predictions are only as good as our models. I work on making species distribution models more reliable by building in ecological realism.

title: Biodiversity Forecasting
text:
The Limitation of Correlative Models
Most species distribution models work by correlating where species occur with environmental conditions, then projecting to future climates. This works reasonably well for some purposes, but it misses crucial dynamics: Can the species actually disperse to newly suitable areas? Will populations persist through bad years? How do interactions with other species constrain distributions?

title: Biodiversity Forecasting
text:
Process-Based Approaches
I’m interested in models that incorporate these processes explicitly. This means combining species distribution models with population dynamics, dispersal kernels, and mechanistic constraints. The models become more complex, but also more honest about what drives species distributions.
A concrete example: standard models might predict that a species “should” occur in northern Europe by 2050. But if that species only disperses 10 km per generation and there’s 500 km of unsuitable habitat in between, it’s not getting there. Process-based models can capture this.

title: Biodiversity Forecasting
text:
Data Integration
Good models need good data. I work on integrating different data sources (standardised monitoring surveys, citizen science observations, ringing recoveries) to improve both the spatial coverage and the temporal dynamics we can capture. Each data type has biases, but combining them thoughtfully can give us a more complete picture.

title: Conservation Applications
text: I try to make my research useful beyond academia. This means working on questions that matter for conservation practice and collaborating with people who can actually implement the results.

title: Conservation Applications
text:
Large Carnivore Expansion
One line of work I’m proud of focuses on large carnivores in Iberia. Wolves, bears, and lynx are expanding their ranges across Spain and Portugal, which is good news for conservation, but also a management challenge. Where will they go next? Which areas are critical for connectivity? Where are conflicts with humans most likely?
I supervised students who tackled these questions using species distribution models and landscape connectivity analysis. The results identify priority areas for proactive conservation: places where action now could facilitate successful recolonisation rather than scrambling to respond after conflicts emerge.

title: Conservation Applications
text:
Threatened Species Assessment
I’ve also worked on improving population assessments for data-deficient species. Traditional monitoring often suffers from “preferential sampling”, meaning we collect data where it’s convenient, not necessarily where it’s representative. I developed occupancy models that correct for this bias, applied to 22 years of Black Stork monitoring data in Spain.
The resulting population estimates were more robust than previous assessments and contributed to the species’ evaluation in the Spanish Red List.

title: RIMed-Fauna
text: Mediterranean rivers are defined by extremes. Winter floods reshape channels; summer droughts leave only disconnected pools, or nothing at all. This hydrological variability creates unique challenges for wildlife, and climate change is making these extremes more intense.

title: RIMed-Fauna

title: RIMed-Fauna
text:
The Project
RIMed-Fauna investigates how terrestrial vertebrates (mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians) adapt to the temporal dynamics of Mediterranean river systems. We’re working in Spanish National Parks to understand:

Which species depend on river corridors and how?
Where are critical refugia during drought?
How will predicted changes in river flow affect wildlife communities?

title: RIMed-Fauna
text:
My Role
I contribute species distribution modelling expertise and supervise Claudia Mediavilla’s MSc research within the project. We’re building models that integrate hydrological variability with wildlife occurrence data, a methodological challenge because most SDM approaches assume static environments.
We’re also deploying camera traps to monitor wildlife use of riparian habitats across seasons.

title: INTRADISP
text:
When we talk about “how far species X disperses,” we’re glossing over enormous variation. Within any species, some individuals stay close to home while others travel hundreds of kilometres. This isn’t random noise; it reflects individual condition, local density, habitat quality, and other factors we’re only beginning to understand.
This variation matters. If we want to predict how species will respond to climate change, we can’t just use average dispersal distances. A population might expand rapidly or barely move at all, depending on which individuals are dispersing and under what conditions.

title: INTRADISP
text:
What We’re Doing
INTRADISP uses the EURING ring-recovery database to quantify intraspecific dispersal variation across European bird species. We’re asking:

How much does dispersal vary within species compared to between species?
What environmental and individual factors predict this variation?
Can we build dispersal models that account for context-dependence?

title: Animal movement and dispersal
text: Animal movement connects individuals to their environment across scales: from daily foraging decisions to seasonal migrations across continents. Understanding these movements is central to ecology and conservation, because they determine how populations are connected, how species track changing environments, and how individuals find resources and mates.

title: Animal movement and dispersal
text:
Dispersal: the missing piece
Dispersal (the movement of individuals from their birthplace to where they breed) drives almost everything in ecology. It determines gene flow, shapes range boundaries, allows colonisation of new areas, and rescues declining populations. Yet for most species, we simply don’t know how far individuals disperse.
Traditional approaches to studying dispersal face a fundamental challenge: you need to track individuals from birth to breeding, which is logistically impossible at large scales. Radio-tracking gives detailed data but for tiny sample sizes. Genetic methods tell you about long-term patterns but miss the ecological timescales we care about.

title: Animal movement and dispersal
section: Estimating dispersal from bird ringing data
text:
Estimating dispersal from bird ringing data
I’ve been working with bird ringing data: millions of records from decades of systematic marking across Europe. The challenge is that these data weren’t designed to study dispersal; they’re full of biases (ringers cluster near cities, recoveries depend on human density, etc.).
Together with collaborators, I developed Bayesian methods that account for these biases and extract reliable dispersal estimates. This produced the first standardised dispersal kernels for over 200 European bird species (Fandos et al. 2023, JAE).

title: Animal movement and dispersal
text:
What we have found
The big surprise from this work? Long-distance dispersal is far more common than we thought. Even “sedentary” species occasionally move hundreds of kilometres. This matters because these rare long-distance events are exactly what drive range expansions and maintain connectivity between distant populations.
I’m now exploring why dispersal varies so much within species. The same species can show very different dispersal patterns depending on population density, habitat quality, or individual condition. Understanding this context-dependence is crucial for predicting how species will respond to environmental change.

title: Research
text: My research focuses on the ecological processes that drive the distribution and abundance of animal populations. I combine fieldwork, large-scale data synthesis (bird ringing, citizen science), and quantitative modelling to tackle questions across spatial and temporal scales.

title: Research
text:
Research Lines


Biodiversity Conservation and Global Change
Habitat degradation and climate change are altering species distributions worldwide. I work on anticipating which species face the greatest threats, understanding why, and identifying where and when problems will emerge.



Animal Movement in Dynamic Landscapes
Linking the process of animal movement to ecology and evolution. How do daily movements, seasonal migration, and lifetime dispersal events shape population connectivity, range boundaries, and species responses to environmental change?



Improving Biodiversity Monitoring and Modelling
Effective conservation requires well-designed monitoring and the capacity to anticipate future changes. I develop species distribution models that incorporate ecological processes (dispersal, population dynamics, species interactions) and integrate multiple data sources.



Field Technology
Camera trapping, bioacoustic monitoring (using AudioMoth devices), and other sensor-based approaches for wildlife monitoring. I am developing field technology pipelines for biodiversity assessment in collaboration with Raul Bonal on bioacoustics.

title: Research
text:
Approach
My work typically combines big datasets and quantitative methods:

Ring-recovery data from EURING and national schemes, one of the largest individual-level animal movement datasets in the world
Citizen science observations (especially eBird)
Bayesian hierarchical models implemented in R
Camera trapping and bioacoustic monitoring in the field

I am committed to open science. Code and data for my papers are available on GitHub and archived on Zenodo.
